top_comment.text:
Great video allthough I have to say I didn't feel very amused when you were 
talking about Belgian people not knowing the rules about left lane 
driving.. I am pretty sure I've done a lot more kilometers in Germany than 
you and I can assure you as a Belgian I know the rules very well. Be 
careful with generalizing and please do not make to much publicity for the 
German autobahn , i don't think the Germans would be very happy about 
getting all sorts of inexperienced Americans on their roads at speeds 
they're unfamiliar with..﻿
top_comment.author: Randy Schouteere (rschoute)

comments.text:
+Randy Schouteere , I would agree with you, I don't feel amused too for 
stating that Belgians don't know how to respectfully drive. I would state 
that Flemish people don't know how to properly do that (generally, not all 
of them of course). I lived 25 years around Brussel & Leuven, moved to 
Vielsalm, the Ardennes. 24 km from the German border, 17 km from the 
Luxembourg border. If I have to go to Brussels, it's ok to drive ... untill 
you pass the Flemish Brabant border ... then nobody respects the right lane 
driving rule anymore, most of them just stick to the middle, and between 
Tienen & Brussels it's the worst. This associal behavior is something you 
don't see that much (almost not) on the highways of the French part of 
Belgium, more specifically, the Ardennes. I've driven +25K km in Germany & 
Luxembourg last year, 15K in the Ardennes & 10K in the Flemish part of 
Belgium, 4K in France, 3K in Spain. Luxembourg has even better drivers then 
Germany. Flemish come last, Ardennes & Germans are pretty close ... 
Spain & France, on the countryroads had most respect for motorcycles (they 
let you through without you asking).
comments.author: FreEntity

comments.text:
mr nagmashot , I don't see the connection between driving on the autobahn 
and the american army..  and btw there were also a lot of belgian soldiers 
present in Germany in the cold war period. German is our 3rd language 
because a part of Belgium is German speaking.. ;-)
comments.author: Randy Schouteere (rschoute)

comments.text:
we had more americans for many years in Germany than belgian people  ;) It 
was called cold war and they here with the US Army. You easy could id them 
with their US licens plates. It was the good old days for me... a hord of 
young US soldiers on party tour through town was way more relaxed than the 
today groups of wanna bee russian and turk gangster kids with thier shit 
language who think they are the coolest chief gangster in town. In the good 
old days the US soldiers regulary smacked them up if they tryed to hard to 
be cooler than they are and if 20 turks tryed to make trouble they always 
outnumbered them within minutes.
The other good thing for us we regulary saw all sorts of US cars not sold 
in Europe... I really miss that time, all was easyer ... in the east was 
the big red enemy and we were here on the other side of the wall brother in 
arms, party together enjoy life together, trained together...
comments.author: nagmashot

comments.text:

top_comment.text:
The Autobahn is a bit of a myth. I drove from Denmark to Italy and back 
this summer and unrestricted sections were few and far between. The quality 
of the road surfaces were surprisingly poor and road construction came up 
about every ten or fifteen miles. I was shocked to enter Italy and go on a 
toll road as smooth as silk all the way from Verona to Naples and because 
it was a toll road it was uncongested with an 80 mph limit (which becomes 
the minimum required in the minds of Italians).﻿
top_comment.author: trefod

What the guy actually said was Germany has better level of driver etiquette 
that Poland, Italy, Belgium and the United States. How is that so hard to 
believe? Where I come from people seem to think that sitting in the fast 
lane is okay because "I pay my taxes too", whilst in Germany you can get 
fined for doing the same thing. It's just a statement about driver

comments.author: Darryl Ware

top_comment.text:
This is probably the best car video ever made. Not just because of the 
amazing car, but because of the driver. I am from Germany and have been 
saying 100% the exact same thing as him for years. Drivers in the U.S are 
super uneducated about how driving works. Each one seems to think the own 
the road. Only here is it ok to go 20 MPH under the already ridiculously 
slow seed limit in the far left lane on the interstate. When I was in 
Germany just a few months back I too was saddened to see all the 
construction work, but at the same time, the Germans are serious about 
their roads and want only the best, unlike here in the U.S where 4 foot 
deep potholes are acceptable on interstates where people attempt to do 70+ 
MPH. There is truly nothing like the German roadway system to include the 
famous Autobahn. There is a reason why the world's best drives come from 
Germany.﻿
top_comment.author: deutschland2680

captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

Every city in the world
can be identified
by one single shot--

Paris, the Eiffel Tower; Rio,
Christ the Redeemer; and New
York, Times Square.
But what about Los Angeles?
That's right.

10 million people in Los Angeles
could be identified by

the inefficient transportation
system.

20,000 miles of roadway and
a majority of it sucks.

Every single day, 92 million
vehicle miles are driven
within the county borders.

It's one of the biggest car
markets in the world, so much

so that car manufacturers design
and engineer cars with
the California market in mind.

Some even consider it the car
capital of the world.

All these high-horsepower cars
sold within the city, and even

with eight-lane-wide highways,
they sometimes come to a
standstill.

What good is all that potential
performance when you
can't take advantage of it?

So what exactly is
the problem?

Well, obviously, the volume
of cars is one variable.

But could it also be the
education and the experience
of the drivers on the road?

And to answer that question,
we've come to
southwestern Germany.

Just over that way is France,
in about five miles.

But we're heading to Munich,
which is that way, 230 miles.

That's about the same distance
between New York and Boston.

Sometimes, that trip takes
up to eight hours,
on a good day, four.

But today, we're going to go
as fast as we can through

Southern Germany and then
on to the Autobahn.

And we're going to try to figure
out, well, is it about

the education of the drivers
in this country
that make it so good.

Or is it about the cars and
the infrastructure?

And we've got the perfect car
for the job, the new Audi RS7.

Now we only have one day to
shoot this whole film and get

to Munich, so this is going
to be very interesting.

All our gear is in this car,
and we have one support

vehicle that's meeting
us halfway.

This is a true and authentic
story of getting across
Germany as fast as possible.

We started our journey
on the roads
through the Black Forest.

Roads, which many of the best
German sports cars have been
tested by company engineers--

long, twisty, and not so much
traffic, even by European
holiday standards.

So why did we choose the Audi
RS7 for this story?

Well, it's a proper
German saloon.

And on all these roads,
especially on the Autobahn, I

don't think I would want
anything else.

You want something that's big,
powerful, and especially with

all of our gear, it kind of
simulates if you're taking a

week-long trip throughout
Europe.

When you're going down these
long country roads that do

have some dips and undulation
to them, this air suspension
is actually very good.
I have no complaints.

Which is important for the
journey, as while dashing

across the country, you'll
never actually find the
straight shot.

They've done a great job with
the suspension to make it feel
nimble on the road.

It's got a big footprint,
but it feels nimble.
[CAR ENGINE]
The sound--

the sound in the cabin is
not that loud, to be
quite honest with you.

But when you go outside, and you
hear the car passing by on
its own, oh my god.
[CAR ENGINE]

On the car we're driving right
now, we've got the equipped

heads-up display, which the
more and more I use it, I

wouldn't want it
any other way.

You concentrate so much
better on the road.
Ah, so much power.

Now in the performance
department, up front you've

got a 4-liter twin-turbo V8
pushing about 560 horsepower
and 512 pound-feet of torque.

This is the top of
the line RS.
It comes from Quattro GmbH.

Again, Quattro GmbH is a whole
separate company from Audi.

They have their own
VIN number style.

They build cars with a
performance mindset, much like
M, much like AMG.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now the purpose of today's trip
is to drive as fast as

possible, legally, from one side
of Germany to the other

and to discover if it's really
about the infrastructure, the

roadway network, or about
the drivers behind the
wheel of the car.

I think one of the greatest
parts of driving in Germany is

that there are systems in place,
and everyone respects
those systems.

Spirited driving on mountain
and country roads, it's
acceptable.
[CAR ENGINE]

But in return, extremely low
speed limits in villages, and
everyone just respects that.

Now, everyone knows that there
are driving standards.

The process to get your license
is much more difficult

in Germany than any other
country in the world.

It's that seriousness that
makes it special.

It's the respect of how the
system works, and everyone
follows it.

As a driver, you're not the one,
you're the one of many.

And everyone is on
the same page.
[CAR ENGINE]
Unlimited speeds?
Absolutely.

But you respect the rules
that do exist.

I think that's one of the
biggest problems we have in

the United States is that the
driver education doesn't teach
you things like this.

No one adheres to any
